document: IPC Section 302: Punishment for murder. Whoever commits murder shall be punished with death, or imprisonment for life, and shall also be liable to fine.
IPC Section 420: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property...
IPC Section 376: Punishment for rape. Whoever commits rape shall be punished with rigorous imprisonment of not less than 10 years, which may extend to life, and shall also be liable to fine.

IPC Section 307: Attempt to murder. Whoever does any act with such intention or knowledge, and under such circumstances that, if he by that act caused death, he would be guilty of murder, shall be punished with imprisonment up to 10 years, and shall also be liable to fine.
IPC Section 498A: Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty...
IPC Section 34: Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention...
IPC Section 120B: Punishment of criminal conspiracy...
The Consumer Protection Act, 2019 aims to protect the interests of consumers and establishes authorities for timely and effective administration and settlement of consumer disputes.
The Information Technology Act, 2000 provides legal recognition to electronic transactions and facilitates e-governance, cybercrime prevention, and data security.
The Right to Information Act, 2005 empowers citizens to request information from public authorities, promoting transparency and accountability.
The Environment Protection Act, 1986 provides for the protection and improvement of environment and matters connected therewith.
The Information Technology (Intermediary Guidelines and Digital Media Ethics Code) Rules, 2021 lay down responsibilities for social media platforms, OTT platforms, and digital news.
Criminal Procedure Code (CrPC) Bail Rules provide conditions and procedures for granting bail to accused persons.
Indian Evidence Act, 1872 lays down rules of evidence admissibility in judicial proceedings.
Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala (1973): The Supreme Court held that the basic structure of the Constitution cannot be amended by Parliament.

metadata.title: Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala

document: Maneka Gandhi vs Union of India (1978): The Supreme Court expanded the interpretation of Article 21, stating that 'procedure established by law' must be just, fair, and reasonable.

metadata.title: Maneka Gandhi vs Union of India

document: Olga Tellis vs Bombay Municipal Corporation (1986): The court held that the right to livelihood is included in the right to life under Article 21.
Indira Sawhney vs Union of India (1992): The Supreme Court upheld 27% reservation for OBCs but capped total reservation at 50%.

metadata.title: Indira Sawhney vs Union of India

document: Vishaka vs State of Rajasthan (1997): The Supreme Court laid down guidelines against sexual harassment at workplace.
NALCO vs Pressteel (2002): The Supreme Court clarified the scope of arbitration agreements under the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996.
Shayara Bano vs Union of India (2017): The Supreme Court declared triple talaq unconstitutional.

metadata.title: Shayara Bano vs Union of India

document: M Siddiq vs Mahant Suresh Das (2019): The Supreme Court ruled in favour of Ram Lalla Virajman in the Ayodhya land dispute.
Article 370: Special status to Jammu and Kashmir, providing it autonomy over internal matters except defense, foreign affairs, and communications.
Article 21: No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.
Article 19: Guarantees six fundamental freedoms including speech and expression, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
Kedar Nath Singh vs State of Bihar (1962): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutionality of sedition law but restricted its application to acts inciting violence.

metadata.title: Kedar Nath Singh vs State of Bihar

document: ADM Jabalpur vs Shivkant Shukla (1976): The Supreme Court held that during Emergency, the right to life under Article 21 could be suspended.
Navtej Singh Johar vs Union of India (2018): The Supreme Court decriminalized homosexuality by striking down Section 377 IPC.

metadata.title: Navtej Singh Johar vs Union of India

document: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy vs Union of India (2017): The Supreme Court recognized the right to privacy as a fundamental right under Article 21.

metadata.title: Justice K.S. Puttaswamy vs Union of India

document: M.C. Mehta vs Union of India (1987): The Supreme Court introduced the principle of absolute liability in environmental law.

metadata.title: M.C. Mehta vs Union of India

document: Bachan Singh vs State of Punjab (1980): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity of death penalty but restricted it to the 'rarest of rare' cases.

metadata.title: Bachan Singh vs State of Punjab

document: Article 32: Provides the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights.
Article 14: Guarantees equality before law and equal protection of laws within the territory of India.
The Family Courts Act, 1984 provides for establishment of Family Courts to promote conciliation and secure speedy settlement of disputes relating to marriage and family affairs.
Kartar Singh vs State of Punjab (1994): The Supreme Court upheld the constitutional validity of TADA but issued safeguards against misuse.

metadata.title: Kartar Singh vs State of Punjab
